results.description:
BIO: Eric Brown has been tinkering with computers for well over 30 years now. Eric's first computer was an Intellivision ECS system and his first real "hack" was using BASIC and the PEEK command to display images and other interesting content from whatever game cartridge happened to be plugged in at the time. He loves programming, keeping up with technology as well as many of the different aspects of the InfoSec space. 

TOPIC: InfoSec for developers: High Level Introduction. 

It seems almost every day we hear in the news about company X was breached, as time goes one we learn the nasty details like how many customers were affected by the breach. Some in more recent history include Home Depot, Target, Jimmy Johns and Dairy Queen. What, as developers can we do to make life just a tad more difficult for these hackers to break into our systems and steal sensitive data?
results.name: JaxDug: InfoSec for developers: High Level Introduction.

results.description:
Have you had a project laying around that you've wanted to get to, but didn't know where to start? Have you visited your local makerspace yet?
Jaxhax has tools and people that can help. Our new meetup schedule for new members is the first Thursday of every month. Members are issued a 24/7 RFID key to access the space whenever they need to work on a project. Read more about member projects and membership on our website at www.jaxhax.org

 

Openhouses are now held the first Thursday of every month for new members.
results.how_to_find_us: Enter the building on the east side, with the fence, go up the stairwell closest to the road with the Jaxhax sign on the door, we're on the second floor. If it's locked press the doorbell or call 561-602-6605
results.name: Monthly Makerspace Openhouse for New Members

results.description:
The book club is back! We'll pick up where we last left with, "Practical Object Oriented Design In Ruby."

To give new readers an opportunity to catch-up, and previous readers an opportunity to refresh we'll start with chapters 1 - 5.

During this meeting we'll discuss the book and the book club format. Let's set the stage for great opportunities to learn and sharpen our developer skill set!

See you there!
results.name: Book Club: Practical Object Oriented Design In Ruby - Ch 1-5

results.description:
Location: 


FSCJ Downtown Campus
Advanced Technology Center (ATC)

(Room T-112) 
101 W. State Street, Jacksonville, FL 32202

TekSystems is providing
breakfast: Panera
lunch: Angie's Subs 

Guest  speaker(s) TBA


Universal Apps hands on demo and talk. 


Come learn new tips and tricks for developing award winning Windows 8 and Windows Phone 8 apps  

breakfast, lunch and afternoon coffee will be provided  

This will be a hands-on hackathon so be sure to bring your laptop preconfigured with Visual Studio 2013, including the Windows Phone SDK.



------- IMPORTANT DETAILS AND HACKATHON RULES -------

At the hackathon, you will be provided with a handful of app challenges to choose from, hand picked by the event organizers because they should be able to be completed or mostly completed in a day. Sample code and other resources will be provided, along with expert help from mentors. These challenges will include but are not limited to apps that use NFC communications, Nokia Maps, and the phone's camera.



So what can you walk away with by participating in this event? 


we will have some giveaways for registered geeks and special prizes for apps published within 2 weeks



What do I need to bring?


Bring your own Windows 8 laptop if possible. There will be a very limited number of systems available if you do not have this, but not nearly enough for everyone. Please let us know in advance if you need access to a PC.

Most but not all challenges require the app be developed for Windows Phone 8. The Windows Phone 8 development tools only run on Windows 8 (64 bit) systems. You will need the Windows Phone 8 SDK installed, and it is highly recommended you do this ahead of time, download here http://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=35471

If you don't have a Windows 8 machine, all is not lost. If you have Windows 7 or Vista you can develop apps for Windows Phone 7. You will be limited in the challenges you can develop for, but will still qualify for all of the promotions. Please install the Windows Phone 7.1 SDK ahead of time, link: http://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=27570
results.name: App Camp Day Jax hackathon +UX Designers Welcome

results.description:
SPACE IS LIMITED - PLS REGISTER TO BE ABLE TO ATTEND.

presentation starts at 6pm

"Xamarin.Forms in XAML" by Brady Merkel


Come join us for a presentation on using XAML with Xamarin.Forms to build apps for Windows Phone, Android, and iOS

bio:

Brady Merkel is a long-time Jacksonville technology junkie. You'll often find him at a user group meeting sitting in front and heckling the speaker. As a life-long learner, Brady has added many programming languages to his tool belt, but favors C# and MVVM/XAML. When he's not solving technical issues, he's dreaming up new ones on his boat!

Feel free to bring your laptop with the latest copy of Xamarin to follow along 


Download free trial at 

http://xamarin.com/platform
results.name: Xamarin.Forms in XAML(write once and run on iOS, Android and WP) by Brady Merkel

results.description:
Join The JOMM and Tommy Hobin of DiscoverTec discussing Defining Your Process.

Internet marketing is a broad topic. With strategy comes process, with process comes efficiency - and of course with efficiency comes more strategy. Because there are so many channels online to potentially market your clients, processes are necessary to set expectations, keep up with trends and most importantly bill your clients fairly. Every step of your strategy needs a process. 

From pitching a prospective client to maintaining your hard-earned #1 position on the Google SERP's, processes run our business. Learn how to understand, build and maintain your process to help your clients and your business. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7am8zxxZsGI&feature=youtu.be

RSVP Today! Complimentary snacks, beer, and wine included with ticket.

*Ticket fee goes toward event space, refreshments and event costs.
results.name: Defining Your Processes

group.name: Jacksonville Online Marketing for Businesses & Entrepreneurs

results.description: First meetup! Whew! Exciting. Let's get together, chat about C5's latest major release, discuss some of the learning curves, and chat about about projects we're working on.
results.name: November Meetup

results.description:
Joe Sam (conceptGo) will present and explain the code for a JavaFX Raffle program with an Eight Ball metaphor. The program uses Java/JavaFX 8 features like streams of lines and lambdas, including method references. JavaFX capabilities discussed include:
- Stages, Scenes, and Nodes
- Layouts
- File selection
- Image loading, presentation, animations, and fades
- ListViews with data transfer via buttons or drag and drop
- Using MediaPlayer to play MP3 audio
- Preview of JavaFX dialogs ( to be available in Java8u40 )
- CSS examples in JavaFX

Finally, the program will be used to raffle several books with Java 8 tee shirts. Titles include "Java SE 8 for the Really Impatient" and "Java SE 8 for Programmers", among others. There will also be assorted Java trinkets available, and JCP 15th Anniversary M&M's for everyone. If you RSVP via the MeetUp page, your name will be automatically included in the raffle, otherwise your name will be collected at the meeting.

Joe Sam Shirah is a consultant, developer and owner of conceptGO ( www.conceptgo.com ), a project oriented resource for businesses. He was the first Duke Dollars leader for over a year and a half, and received the Java Community Award at JavaOne. He has been moderator for several JGuru and IBM developerWorks forums. Joe Sam has written numerous articles and tutorials, as well as being tech editor and reviewer for several books. The meeting is sponsored by TEKsystems.
results.name: November Meeting: a JavaFX Raffler with Java 8 Features by Joe Sam Shirah

results.description:
There will not be October meetup as the rooms are taken by early voting.

Is that time again, we will have a Melee in November, so hone your skills and prepare something cool to show off.  See rules below

-------------------------------------------------------------------------

This is how the melee will run:

We will provide a picture to start

If you won one of the Topaz Lab filters, please prepare something where you can apply them for the melee.

Every attendant will have a two minute interval to use his/her Photoshop powers and knowledge to enhance/modify the picture

What you can do:

• Add props to the environment.  You can bring any graphics or cut outs in a USB drive) or make them accessible on-line (no password protected, so it is easily accessible)

• Add effects

• Enhance the picture

• Slight deformations

 What you cannot do:

• Undo previous changes

• Remove the main subject of the picture

• Change the main subject so much that is not recognizable
results.how_to_find_us: Room E  small room inside the library at your left after the service desk
results.name: Photoshop Melee

results.description: The Jacksonville Linux Users' Group (JaxLUG) is a monthly meeting dedicated to providing free (as in speech) information to anyone interested in participating. Our presentations vary widely, including beginners Linux installation and usage, network configuration, software installation and configuration, information security, advanced scripting, and much more. Our presentations are by members of the community, and suggestions are always welcome if there's a subject you'd like to know more about!
results.name: JaxLUG- Jacksonville Linux User Group

results.description:
Joshua Plicque from Elva Marketing will be presenting on Firebase, the recently acquired by Google real time backend API tool.

Firebase: The Node Killer?

Building an application is full of tedious and difficult tasks. Nearly every app needs a database, an API, and authentication. With Firebase — all of this is done for you. With just a few lines of code, you can be up and running with real-time data updates with persistence.Firebase has full-featured libraries for all major web and mobile platforms and bindings for the most popular frameworks.
Come get more acquainted with Firebase and discover if it's ease of use is enough to dethrone Node as the de-facto standard for real-time applications.
results.name: Firebase

results.name: Let's all have dinner at the Golden Corral!

results.description:
Cash In By Caching Out Of Process

Out of process or "distributed" caching is essential to any large-scale application's performance. This session will teach you how to use distributed caching to scale any application, with strong focus on web apps. Specific topics include an overview of distributed caching, comparing the benefits and drawbacks of distributed caching to traditional in process caching, and alleviating database load with a caching layer. Multiple demonstrations of distributed caching will be provided using the .NET framework, though the session is intended to be applicable to all frameworks, technologies, and stacks.

Biography

David Haney is a developer on the core team at Stack Exchange, creators of question and answer websites such as StackOverflow and ServerFault. He spends his days paradoxically using StackOverflow to solve programming problems in the StackOverflow codebase. He was previously a lead developer on Fanatics' e-commerce platform which hosts over 10,000 websites including the NFLShop - The Official Online Shop of the NFL and NBAStore.com - The Official NBA Store. David is the creator of Dache, an open source distributed caching framework. His spare time is spent drinking beer and participating in community user groups and programming events - often simultaneously.

As always, it'll be a laid back atmosphere with beer, pizza, and ping pong! 

Please call Katie [masked]) if you have any issues. 

Schedule: 

5:30-6:15 Beer, Pizza, and Socializing

6:15-6:30 Book Giveaways, Introductions

6:30-7:30 Cash in by Caching Out of Process

7:30-8:00 Questions and Closing Remarks
results.name: Cash In by Caching Out of Process

Tech On Tap

results.description:
While relational databases sit at the core of most of today’s applications, they are not always the best fit for certain data needs. That’s why when building applications with rich connections, analyzing trends and seeing commonalities within data, developers at places like Cisco, Adobe and Twitter have increasingly turned to graph databases. In this discussion, we'll dive into Neo4j, a popular graph database, and demonstrate how to solve complex, connected data problems with a look at examples demonstrating the power, speed and simplicity of using graph databases. We'll close with a look at some caveats as well as glimpse into the future of graph databases.

(Jeremy is a father, a web developer, a public speaker, an open source contributor, and an amateur photographer. He currently resides in his hometown of Memphis, TN, and works as the CTO and Lead Developer at Graph Story, the leading graph-as-a-service provider.)
results.name: Jeremy Kendall: Leveraging the Power of Graph Databases in PHP

results.description: Integration Services is a powerful data integration tool that allows you Extract, Transform and Load (ETL) data to fit your business needs. In this session you will learn how the basics of how SSIS fits into your BI ecosystem and how to get started using it in your environment.

meta.title: Meetup Open Events v2
meta.description: Searches for recent and upcoming public events hosted by Meetup groups. Its search window  is the past one month through the next three months, and is subject to change. Open Events is optimized to search for current events by location, category, topic, or text, and only lists Meetups that have **3 or more RSVPs**. The number or results returned with each request is not guaranteed to be the same as the page size due to secondary filtering. If you're looking for a particular event or events within a particular group, use the standard [Events](/meetup_api/docs/2/events/) method.
